title: Euler's Partition Theorem
description: The number of partitions of n into odd parts equals the number of partitions into distinct parts. A beautiful bijection in combinatorics.

meta.author: Leonhard Euler (1748)
originalContributions: Framework for partitions into odd vs distinct parts

overview.historicalContext: Euler discovered this theorem while studying partition generating functions. It reveals a surprising connection between two seemingly different partition types. The theorem has inspired centuries of work in partition theory, including Ramanujan's famous congruences.
overview.problemStatement:
**Euler's Partition Theorem**: For any positive integer n:

(# of partitions of n into odd parts) = (# of partitions of n into distinct parts)

For example, for n=5: odd parts: 5, 3+1+1, 1+1+1+1+1 (3 partitions); distinct: 5, 4+1, 3+2 (3 partitions).
overview.proofStrategy: Euler's proof uses generating functions: sum over n of p_odd(n)x^n = product of 1/(1-x^(2k-1)) equals product of (1+x^k) = sum of p_distinct(n)x^n. A bijective proof converts partitions via binary representation of multiplicities.
keyInsights: Generating functions encode partition counts elegantly
The bijection uses binary expansion of part multiplicities
Foundation for the theory of q-series

conclusion.summary: Euler's partition theorem is a gem of combinatorics, revealing unexpected symmetry in how numbers can be decomposed. It sparked the rich field of partition theory.
conclusion.implications: Applications include statistical mechanics, representation theory, and modular forms. The theorem leads to deeper identities like the Rogers-Ramanujan identities.
openQuestions: What other partition identities await discovery?
